thread.title: Labor to vote for gay marriage - in years from now |
thread.title_full: Labor to vote for gay marriage - in years from now | The Advertiser

author: PETER JEAN POLITICAL REPORTER
title: Labor to vote for gay marriage - in years from now |
text:
LABOR will continue to allow a conscience vote on same-sex marriage for at least another term of Parliament, under a last-minute deal hatched to save Opposition Leader Bill Shorten from a humiliating defeat at his party’s national conference.
Deputy Labor Leader Tanya Plibersek and Senate Leader Penny Wong almost succeeded in a push to change the party rules to allow the expulsion of MPs and senators who voted against marriage equality.
But under a compromise brokered by Mr Shorten, a conscience vote on same-sex marriage will be allowed until the election after next.
If same-sex marriage is not established before that time, it would become Labor policy to support it.
The Labor leader supports marriage equality but also argued that party members should not be forced to toe the official line on the issue.
Mr Shorten urged Prime Minister Tony Abbott to allow Liberal MPs a conscience vote on marriage equality. Labor MPs Anthony Albanese, Penny Wong, Bill Shorten, Tanya Plibersek and Louise Pratt celebrate passing the marriage equality amendment at Labor national conference. Picture: Hamish Blair Source: News Corp Australia
“We lay down the challenge to Mr Abbott and his liberals, please give your members of Parliament a free vote so we can make equality a reality now,’’ he said.
If same-sex marriage was not legalised in Australia before the next election, Mr Shorten said he would introduce a marriage equality bill into parliament within 100 days of becoming Prime Minister.
A tearful Senator Wong thanked delegates to the Labor Conference for agreeing to abolish the party’s support for a conscience vote after the next term of federal parliament.
Senator Wong, who is gay, said the party should never have had a conscience vote on marriage equality and recalled being forced by the party to vote in 2004 “for my own discrimination.’’
She said she hoped marriage equality was approved by Parliament before the next election.
“I want to win it sooner — I want to win it in this parliament,’’ Senator Wong said.
Mr Shorten said the long phase-out of the conscience vote would help demonstrate to people who opposed same-sex marriage that they were still welcome in the Labor Party.
“I understand there are sincerely-held views contrary to the proposition of marriage equality,’’ he said.
“The Labor Party is still a party that says to people of religious faith you are welcome in our party’’.
South Australian Labor Senator Alex Gallacher, who opposes same-sex marriage, reacted calmly to the decision to phase out the conscience vote.
“The can has been kicked well and truly down the road,’’ he said.
The conference vote occurred after Labor’s Left faction decided to push for the abolition of the conscience vote on marriage equality.
Senior members of Labor’s Left, including Anthony Albanese and Kim Carr, spoke out against their faction’s hard line.
The Australian Christian Lobby condemned the Labor Conference’s decision on marriage equality.
The three-day conference in Melbourne ended Sunday night.
The conference voted to scrap the requirement for party members to also hold union membership.
The party also endorsed a proposal for 50 per cent of election candidate to be women.
Proposals for rank-and-file Labor members to get more say on the preselection of Senate candidates were voted down.
